title: CMOs Expect Bigger Marketing Budgets, Despite Economic Concerns
text:
Recession fears are rising and companies are scrutinizing their spending, but top marketers still think they’ll get more money to spend next year, a new Gartner Inc. survey says.

Some 61% of senior marketing leaders expect their marketing budgets to grow in 2020, according to the survey. That contrasts with the recent trend toward budgets that are roughly flat, most recently slipping to 10.5% of company revenue this year from 11.2% in 2018, Gartner found.

And 86% of respondents said the political and economic environment would have a positive impact on their business results in the next 18 to 24 months, according to Gartner. The research and advisory firm surveyed 342 marketers in North America and the U.K. at companies with $500 million or more in revenue.

Newsletter Sign-up

Consumers slowed spending and businesses cut back in August, meanwhile, as economic warning signs accumulate.

Marketers seem to be isolating themselves from broader concerns, said Ewan McIntyre, a vice president and analyst at Gartner. “I speak to you from the U.K., where we have a huge amount of uncertainty around what’s going to happen around Brexit, and that of course is not isolated to the EU,” he said. “There’s also the impact of trade tariffs and just generally the uncertainty in the wider business context.”

But Lone Thomsen, a former Coca-Cola Co. executive who’s now global chief marketing officer at Meatless Farm Co. in the U.K., said marketers may be justified.

The prolonged Brexit process has probably made some marketers hold back a bit, Ms. Thomsen allowed. “But I think that will pick up again as soon as this thing has been settled,” she said.

And marketers in general have a case for greater budgets because they need to invest in new capabilities including marketing technology, Ms. Thomsen said.

The U.S. and the U.K. are distinct cases, said Brian Wieser, global president of business intelligence at WPP PLC’s media-agency conglomerate GroupM. “In the U.S., it feels like there’s nothing that’s stopping growth from happening in the short term,” he said. “There’s all sort of risks, but from a planning perspective growth continues.”

In the U.K., it’s not clear whether and when Brexit questions will clear up, he said. “The U.K. is just on the edge of who knows what,” he said.

Flexibility is key when uncertainty dominates, another executive said.

Dawn Morris, chief digital banking and marketing officer at First Horizon National Corp. and a respondent in the Gartner survey, said she expects her marketing budget to remain steady next year—to start. If conditions get worse, or if new opportunities arise, the company will adapt, she said.

“We are putting in place much more of an agile marketing capability than we have right now,” Ms. Morris said.

Write to Nat Ives at nat.ives@wsj.com
description: Nearly 90% of marketing executives believe the political and economic environment will benefit their businesses in the next 18 to 24 months, according to a new Gartner survey.
